answers.answer: Many people have a caffeine addiction but really aren't concerned about it.  If you are concerned, you know what you have to do.  Cut back slowly on it.  Instead of having a Pepsi, have a water or orange juice a couple of times a day.I feel like I have a chocolate milk addiction right now.  I could easily drink 4 litres a day.  I just know that it's better than drinking alcohol.

Yes sugar addiction is a real thing. And you can withdraw from it too. I did. I had to step down little by little. My mountain was the last to go. Slowly. I was so tired, headache, nausaus, achy when I tried to cut all at once. So yes some people get a headache, others get the full wds. Try to go to yo a can at a time then decrease that.
Thanks for the help! I'll try to cutback.

Both sugar and caffeine are addictive. If you're just having a cup or two of unsweetened coffee or tea in the morning, caffeine can be a pretty benign addiction (guilty) in the sense that there's no proven detriment to your health. Sugar, especially in soda, is another story. Soda is basically liquid sugar, and too much of it poses some serious health risks (diabetes, obesity) as well as really messing with your mood and energy levels. I'd try weaning off it if you can, it's bad for you for sure.

question: I'm not sure if this even belongs in this section, but it seemed like the only 1 that fit. I feel like I'm addicted to caffeine, if not addicted, possibly borderline. I've been knocking back Pepsi sodas like they're water. When I'm out of it, I think about the taste. It's so good when I drink it. I'm pretty sure it isn't very healthy to intake this much. I often think about the effects it has & can have on my body, in the future. I don't know if it's the sugariness, the caffeine, or both. I bought more today, after remembering I was down to 1 bottle. I'd like some opinions on this, any help would be appreciated.
title: Sugar/Caffeine Addiction?
